4.6 Continued

Private vs. Public key Cryptography
Private key | Definition

A cryptosystem where knowing the encryption function facilitates
knowledge of decryption function

Example 5

Name \qquad\qquad Key \qquad Encryption Function \qquad\qquad Decrption Function

Shift Cipher \qquad     k\space\space\space\space k    k \quad f(p)=p+k mod 26f(p)=p+k\space mod\space 26f(p)=p+k mod 26 \quad\qquad f(p)=p−k mod 26f(p)=p-k\space mod\space 26f(p)=p−k mod 26
Affine transform(a,b) c\space c c \qquad c=a⋅p+b mod 26c=a\cdot p + b\space mod\space 26c=a⋅p+b mod 26 \qquad\quad p≡a¯(c−b)(mod 26)p\equiv \bar{a}(c-b)(mod\space 26)p≡​a​¯​​(c−b)(mod 26)
Block cipher σ\sigmaσ \qquad\qquad σ(p1)=p1~\sigma(p_{1}) = \tilde{p_{1}}σ(p​1​​)=​p​1​​​~​​ \qquad\qquad p1=σ−1(p1~)p_{1} = \sigma ^{-1}(\tilde{p_1})p​1​​=σ​−1​​(​p​1​​​~​​)
\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad σ(p2)=p2~\sigma(p_{2}) = \tilde{p_{2}}σ(p​2​​)=​p​2​​​~​​ \qquad\qquad\qquad p2=σ−1(p2~)p_{2} = \sigma ^{-1}(\tilde{p_2})p​2​​=σ​−1​​(​p​2​​​~​​)
\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad σ(p3)=p3~\sigma(p_{3}) = \tilde{p_{3}}σ(p​3​​)=​p​3​​​~​​\qquad\qquad\quad p3=σ−1(p3~)p_{3} = \sigma ^{-1}(\tilde{p_3})p​3​​=σ​−1​​(​p​3​​​~​​)
\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad σ(pm)=pm~\sigma(p_{m}) = \tilde{p_{m}}σ(p​m​​)=​p​m​​​~​​\qquad\qquad\quad pm=σ−1(pm~)p_{m} = \sigma ^{-1}(\tilde{p_m})p​m​​=σ​−1​​(​p​m​​​~​​)

\quad
\quad

Public Key | definition

A cryptosystem where knowing the encryption does nothing to know the decryption key

Example | RSA

Encryption key: (n, e)

∙\bullet∙ n=p⋅qp⋅q n=p\cdot q\qquad p\cdot q\spacen=p⋅qp⋅q  are large primes (200+) digits

Encryption Method
1.) {A,B,C, ..., Z} -> {00,01,...,25}
2.) Concatenate the digits into one string
3.) Divide the string into k blocks size L
L is the largest number such that
25⋅25⋅⋅⋅25<n25\cdot 25\cdot\cdot\cdot 25 < n25⋅25⋅⋅⋅25<n
L - digits
4.) Now the string is composed of blocks m1,m2,⋅⋅mkm_{1},m_{2},\cdot\cdot m_{k}m​1​​,m​2​​,⋅⋅m​k​​
where each mim_{i}m​i​​ is an integer with L digits. Encrypt each block using
Ci=mie mod n\qquad\qquad C_{i} = m_{i}^{e}\space mod\space nC​i​​=m​i​e​​ mod n
5.) Concatenate the encrypted blocks

Example | Encrypt the given plain text

∙n=p⋅qp⋅qarelargeprimes(200+digits)\bullet n = p\cdot q \qquad p\cdot q are large primes (200+ digits)∙n=p⋅qp⋅qarelargeprimes(200+digits)
∙e∈Z gcd(e,(p−1)(q−1))=1\bullet e \in \mathbb{Z}\space gcd(e,(p-1)(q-1))=1∙e∈Z gcd(e,(p−1)(q−1))=1

Encryption Method

1.) {A,B,C, ...., Z} -> {00,01,...,25}
2.) Concatenate the digits into one string
3.) Divide the string into k blocks size L
L is the largest number such that
25⋅25⋅⋅⋅⋅25<n25\cdot 25\cdot \cdot\cdot\cdot 25 < n25⋅25⋅⋅⋅⋅25<n

4.) Now the string is composed of blocks m1,m2,...,mkm_{1},m_{2},..., m_{k}m​1​​,m​2​​,...,m​k​​
where each mim_{i}m​i​​ is an integer with L digits. Encrypt each block using
Ci=mie mod n\qquad\qquad C_{i}= m_{i}^e\space mod\space nC​i​​=m​i​e​​ mod n

5.) Concatenate the encrypted blocks

Example 6 Encrypt the given plaintext using key

a.) "STOP" with key (2537,13)
Note: i.) 2537 = 43 ⋅\cdot⋅ 59
ii.)gcd(13,42⋅58)=1\qquad ii.) gcd(13,42\cdot 58)=1ii.)gcd(13,42⋅58)=1
1.|2.) 18191415
3.) 2525 < 2537
\qquad L = 4
4.) C1=181913 mod 2537C_{1} = 1819^{13}\space mod\space 2537C​1​​=1819​13​​ mod 2537
C2=141513mod 2537\qquad C_{2}=1415^{13} mod\space 2537C​2​​=1415​13​​mod 2537

Encryption 2081 2182

b.) "upload" (53⋅\cdot⋅ 61, 17)
1.|2. 20 15 11 14 00 03
3.) 2525 < 3233
2015 1114 0003

4.) C1=201517 mod 3233=2545C_{1}=2015^{17}\space mod\space 3233 = 2545C​1​​=2015​17​​ mod 3233=2545
C2=111417 mod 3233=2757C_{2}=1114^{17}\space mod\space 3233 =2757C​2​​=1114​17​​ mod 3233=2757
C3=317 mod3233=1211C_{3}=3^{17}\space mod 3233=1211C​3​​=3​17​​ mod3233=1211

Encryption: 2545 2757 1211
Decryption
Encryption Function: c=me mod nc = m^{e}\space mod\space nc=m​e​​ mod n

Note: 1.) Since gcd(e,(p-1)(q-1)) = 1
∃e¯∈Z\exists \bar{e} \in \mathbb{Z}∃​e​¯​​∈Z such that e¯⋅e≡1(mod(p−1)(q−1))\bar{e}\cdot e\equiv 1 (mod(p-1)(q-1))​e​¯​​⋅e≡1(mod(p−1)(q−1))
in such case
e¯e=k(p−1)(q−1)+1\bar{e}e = k(p-1)(q-1)+1​e​¯​​e=k(p−1)(q−1)+1

2.) Since
C=me mod nC = m^{e}\space mod\space nC=m​e​​ mod n
then, C≡me(mod n)C \equiv m^e(mod\space n)C≡m​e​​(mod n) by thm
So ce¯≡(ne)e¯(mod n) c^{\bar{e}} \equiv (n^e)^{\bar{e}}(mod\space n)\spacec​​e​¯​​​​≡(n​e​​)​​e​¯​​​​(mod n)  by exercise 41

ce¯≡me¯e(mod n)c^{\bar{e}}\equiv m^{\bar{e}e}(mod\space n)c​​e​¯​​​​≡m​​e​¯​​e​​(mod n)
ce¯≡mk(p−1)(q−1)+1(mod n)c^{\bar{e}}\equiv m^{k(p-1)(q-1)+1}(mod\space n)c​​e​¯​​​​≡m​k(p−1)(q−1)+1​​(mod n) by (1)

3.) By Fermat's Little thm
(i) m(p−1)≡1(mod p)m^{(p-1)}\equiv 1(mod\space p)m​(p−1)​​≡1(mod p)
Hence by (1)
ce¯≡(mp−1⋅1k(q−1)+1⋅mod p)\qquad c^{\bar{e}}\equiv (m^{p-1}\cdot 1^{k(q-1)+1}\cdot mod\space p)c​​e​¯​​​​≡(m​p−1​​⋅1​k(q−1)+1​​⋅mod p)
implies
ce¯≡(1)k(q−1)⋅m(mod p)\qquad c^{\bar{e}}\equiv (1)^{k(q-1)}\cdot m(mod\space p)c​​e​¯​​​​≡(1)​k(q−1)​​⋅m(mod p)
ce¯≡m (mod p)\qquad c^{\bar{e}}\equiv m\space (mod\space p)c​​e​¯​​​​≡m (mod p)

By (ii.)
ce¯≡(mq−1)k(p−1)⋅m(mod q)\qquad c^{\bar{e}}\equiv (m^{q-1})^{k(p-1)}\cdot m(mod\space q)c​​e​¯​​​​≡(m​q−1​​)​k(p−1)​​⋅m(mod q)
ce¯≡m(mod q)\qquad c^{\bar{e}}\equiv m(mod\space q)c​​e​¯​​​​≡m(mod q)

Notice
m≡ce¯(mod p)\qquad m\equiv c^{\bar{e}}(mod\space p)m≡c​​e​¯​​​​(mod p) ( * )
m≡ce¯(mod q)\qquad m\equiv c^{\bar{e}}(mod\space q)m≡c​​e​¯​​​​(mod q) ( * )

is a system of linear congruences with a unique solution mod n since gcd(p,q)=1

Solving using Back Substitution
m−ce¯=p⋅kk∈Z\qquad m-c^{\bar{e}}=p\cdot k \qquad k\in \mathbb{Z}m−c​​e​¯​​​​=p⋅kk∈Z
Plug into ( ** )
p⋅k+ce¯≡ce¯ mod q\qquad p\cdot k + c^{\bar{e}}\equiv c^{\bar{e}}\space mod\space qp⋅k+c​​e​¯​​​​≡c​​e​¯​​​​ mod q
k⋅k≡0(mod q)\qquad k\cdot k \equiv 0 (mod \space q)k⋅k≡0(mod q)
k≡0(mod q)\qquad k \equiv 0 (mod\space q)k≡0(mod q)

i.e. q | k k=q⋅sfor s∈Z\qquad k=q\cdot s\qquad for\space s \in \mathbb{Z}k=q⋅sfor s∈Z
m=p⋅k+ce¯\qquad m = p\cdot k+c^{\bar{e}}m=p⋅k+c​​e​¯​​​​
m=p⋅q⋅s+ce¯s∈Z\qquad m = p\cdot q\cdot s +c^{\bar{e}}\qquad s\in\mathbb{Z}m=p⋅q⋅s+c​​e​¯​​​​s∈Z
ce¯=p⋅q(−s)+m\qquad c^{\bar{e}} = p\cdot q (-s)+mc​​e​¯​​​​=p⋅q(−s)+m
m=ce¯mod p⋅q\qquad m = c^{\bar{e}}mod\space p\cdot qm=c​​e​¯​​​​mod p⋅q
m=ce¯ modndecryptionfunction\qquad m = c^{\bar{e}}\space mod n\qquad\qquad decryption functionm=c​​e​¯​​​​ modndecryptionfunction
e¯e≡1(mod(p−1)(q−1))\qquad \bar{e}e \equiv 1 (mod(p-1)(q-1))​e​¯​​e≡1(mod(p−1)(q−1))
e¯e=k(p−1)(q−1)+1\qquad \bar{e}e = k(p-1)(q-1)+1​e​¯​​e=k(p−1)(q−1)+1

Example 7 | Decrypt

a.) 0981 0461 key (2537, 13)
e¯⋅13≡1(mod 42⋅58)\qquad \bar{e}\cdot 13 \equiv 1(mod\space 42\cdot 58)​e​¯​​⋅13≡1(mod 42⋅58)
e¯⋅13≡1(mod 2436)\qquad \bar{e}\cdot13 \equiv 1(mod\space 2436)​e​¯​​⋅13≡1(mod 2436)
e¯=937\qquad \bar{e} = 937​e​¯​​=937
m1=981937mod 2537=704m_{1} = 981^{937}mod\space 2537 = 704m​1​​=981​937​​mod 2537=704
m2=461937mod 2537=1115m_{2} = 461^{937}mod\space 2537 = 1115m​2​​=461​937​​mod 2537=1115
0704 11150704\space 11150704 1115 = HE LP
